Praedictis adiciendum est
Lombardus, Sent., I, d. 34, c. 1, n. 1
. This is distinction 34 in which, after the Master determined about the comparison of properties belonging to each person, here he considers the comparison of persons to the essence. And this is divided into two parts because in the first place he makes determinations about comparisons of this type, in the second place he treats about the extrinsic operations of the persons, beginning in distinction 35,
cumque supra disservimus .

The first part is divided into three because in the first place he treats these comparisons, in the second place he declares the dispositions of some terms, in the third place he makes an epilogue about what has been said. The second begins at
hic considerandum est
Lombardus
. The third begins at
de sacramento unitatis
Lombardus
.

The second principal part, namely distinction 34, in which, after the Master treated the unity of the essence and the three personal supposites, now begins to treat the essential attributes, namely about the knowledge, power, and will. And this is divided into three parts, for in the first place he introduces a question, in the second place regarding this question he recites a double opinion, in the third place he offers his own determination The second begins at
ad hoc autem
Lombardus
. The third begins at
ad hoc iuxta modulum
Lombardus
, etc.

Whether the highest simple essence productive of any producibile thing is eternal cogitative knowledge of any knowable thing; whether the uncreated essence of every knowable thing is eternal knowledge adequate to its immensity.

That not because, if knowledge of God were eternal, it would follow that nothing would precede it. The consequent is false because being precedes living, and living precedes understanding and knowing in creatures, therefore also in the creator.
In the second place, if God were to know all things, it follows that his knowledge would terminate in something external. The consequent seems false, therefore etc.

In the third place, it would follow that God would not know himself before he knows created or creatable things. The consequent seems false because then the direct act would not be prior nor more perfect than the reflexive act.

In opposition is the
Master, in distinction 35
and
Augustine 15 De Trinitate, in chapter 13 de magnis
who says
God does not know created things except through their creation
Augustinus, De Trinitate, XXX
, therefore.

First conclusion: the ratio of understanding and the cognitive act of the uncreated essence are one grade, super simple, and immeasurable adequately to the same essence. This conclusion is clear through
Augustine 15 De Trinitate, in chapter 14
in the simplicity, he says, of this divine nature, to know is different than to be
, and he adds
therefore all the things God the Father knows in himself, he knows in the son
,
similarly he knows all things both the Son and all things which are in the knowledge of them he sees each at the same time, not as particulars or individually as if seen alternatively, but he sees all things at once because there is nothing that he does not always see
, therefore the conclusion is true.

First corollary: the divine will does not make possible the possible before the possible itself is or exists or before the divine intellect understands it. This is clear because otherwise it would follow that the divine will would be the cause of the possibility of sin, which is false.

Second corollary: just as nothing is able to precede the divine science, so nothing is able to exist as the cause of the divine science. This is clear because it is eternal, and because the name of cause is not admitted in the divine, and because the science of God
in an instant of eternity.

Third corollary: though the divine science is terminated cognitively to every intelligible thing, nevertheless not every intelligible thing depends effectively on God. This is clear because God would be the cause of any possibility and impossibility, and in this case God is the prior cause of the impossibility of his own non existence, which is false because nothing is the cause of this.

Second conclusion: though no created thing is able to be actual science of anything probable from itself or another, nevertheless God is all knowledge of any complex or incomplex knowable thing. The first part is proved because concerning anything there are infinite knowable truths, therefore. The consequence holds because no created thing is able to know distinctly at the same time infinite truths. The antecedent is proved because regarding anything there are infinite knowable propositions in connection with other existing or possible things without end. The second part is clear through the first conclusion. Again, this is clear through
Hebrews 4 ,
all things are naked and open to his eyes
Hebraeos 4:13 .

First corollary: the intellect is a thing known intuitively and such a thing is not known abstractively, or it is the case that the intellect is a thing known intuitively and its knowledge is not terminated in such a thing. This is clear because the divine intellect knows all things eternally and intuitively in itself, just as in the exemplative art of those things, therefore. In opposition is
Gregory, distinction 3 of book one, in an article , for he says that
every knowlegdge of a thing in species and its proper likeness not terminating in a thing is abstractive
XXX
.

Second corollary: it is the case that the intellect sees a thing intuitively and that cognition of this type does not depend on anything. This is clear because the knowledge of God is caused by nothing and depends on nothing.

Third corollary: just as any existing thing is intuitively understood by the divine science, so the divine science is terminated to anything known in this way. The first part is clear through what has been said. The second is proved because otherwise God would not understand things existing outside himself, which is false. This part opposes
Alphonsus, in distinction 35
XXX .

Third conclusion: the divine essence knows itself and other things distinct from itself equally first and with an equally immeasurably perfect knowledge. This is clear because from eternity it knew all things, therefore it did so equally first. The consequence is valid, and the antecedent is proved because God does not ever begin to know anew and he is not able to begin to know. But that he knows with an equally perfect knowledge is clear because his essence is his knowledge and his knowing is his being, as is clear through the Master and Augustine

First corollary: just as God knows all distinct beings distinctly, so he knows reflexively no produced or producible thing. This is clear because every divine cognition is correct in highest way, but reflexive cognition seems to convey an imperfection.
Second corollary: though God knows every complex and incomplex thing, nevertheless God knows nothing discursively or complexly. This is clear because to know in this way is a kind of imperfection.

Third corollary: that the divine intellect, while it grasps itself or other things cognitively is in no way made deficient from its proper immensity. This is clear because the divine intellect while knowing the essence apprehends it while comprehending adequately, but the formally immeasurable divine essence is comprehended by its own intellect, therefore the formally immeasurable intellect is adequate to it. This corollary is against the thought of
Saint Thomas
and is perhaps founded on the saying of
Augustine, 83 questions, question 8 ,
everything which he comprehends is finite to itself
Augustinus 83 questiones, q. 8
.

From the super simple essence of immense perfection with respect to creatures it is not able to be called a primary object of divine perfection. This is against
Thomas of Argentina, in distinction 35
who speaks of the divine essence as the primary object of divine cognition and even created things as secondary objects of the same. The corollary
is clear because God knows all things equally first, as was said, then in the second place because the divine essence is not an object for the divine intellect, as infinite perfection, earlier than as a creative and exemplative of things. From this it is clear what should be said to this question.

Against the
first conclusion , it is argued that it is not repugnant to the divine simplicity that the knowledge is less than the substance, therefore the conclusion is false. The consequence holds, and the antecedent is proved because whiteness is able to be more or the likeness less than the whiteness is in itself, and despite this it will not be more composed or more simple, therefore by extension it will not be repugnant to the most simple essence to be less than knowledge than the essence.

In the second place, against the
first corollary , that which has a cause comes later from that which does not have a cause. But the intelligible and possible as such have a cause, therefore the divine will, by the volition which does not have a cause, makes possible the possible itself before it exists This is the argument of the
Profound Doctor, in book 1, chapter 12 and 13
XXX .

Against the second corollary: the divine intellect is the cause of the divine science, therefore it is prior to it. The consequence holds because a cause is prior to its act, as
the same author says in the same place
XXX .

In the fourth place, against the
third corollary
it is argued through
Anselm, in the Monologion , who says that,
every possibility and impossibility is subject to the divine will
Anselmus, Cur Deus Homo, II, c. 17
, therefore every intelligible thing which has no defect depends on the divine will.

Against the second part of the secund conclusion, it follows that God that God knows all continuous parts distinctly, which is false because then, just as he would know these things, so he would be able to divide these things, then it is asked either this division will be able to be divided, and then it would not be evacuated, but if is not be able to be divided, then this is against the
Philosopher, VI Physics
XXX , because a continuum is always divisible into divisible things, otherwise it would be composed from indivisible things and in this respect it would have no quantity, which is impossible.

In the second place, if God were to understand a thing outside himself, then his intellect would be made worse and would be dependent on created things, which is false. The consequence is clear then because everything intellect is made bad or is perfected by its own intellection, and as a consequence his perfection depends on it, and as a consequence by understanding vile things and corporeal things it becomes worse and becomes dependent on these things.

In the third place, if God knew diverse created objects, it follows that there would be a diverse and distinct divine science. This is clear because the diversity of knowledge is caused from the diversity of knowable objects.

In the fourth place, against the corollary, it is said by
Alphonsus
XXX , that
Augustine, in IV On Genesis, chapter 8
XXX , says that God from eternity was examining this
and God does not examine this outside himself, just as we examine with our eyes bodily things that certainly did not yet exist
Augustinus, Book 4, c. 6, n. 12
, and further below,
therefore how God examined this, such that he arranges in this way is on account of the fact that he alone is able to do this
Augustinus, Book 4, c. 6, n. 12
.

Against the third conclusion, it is argued that everything which is known by God in some way is an object to the divine cognitive power, but creatures are known, therefore. But they are not objectified as a primary object, therefore etc.

In the second place, thus the whole multitude of knowable things exceeds the multitude of all things known, therefore God does not know all things distinctly. The consequence is valid, and the antecedent is proved as follows: let a be the whole multitude of possible angels known by God, and let b be the multitude of all souls, and c be all roses, and let d be the composed multitude of b and c only, then it is argued thus that a is equal to b et c separately, therefore a is less than d, therefore a is able to be imagined to grow to equality with d, by which fact God does not thus know distinctly the whole multitude of a which has been increased, therefore the whole multitude of all known things is exceeded by the multitude of all knowable things.

In the third place, thus the multitude of all knowable points and absolute infinity are therefore adequate to the entire capacity of the divine intellect, and as a consequence nothing else is able to be known. The antecedent is proved because, if to this multitude of points one point were added, then this would not have been the multitude of all knowlable points. And the consequence is clear because one absolute infinity is not greater to another absolute infinity.

In the fourth place, if God were to understand everything distinctly, it would follow that he would understood more than he can do. This is clear because he is not able to produce every knowable thing. But the falsity of this is proved because then God would not be omnipotent.

To the first , the antecedent is denied. To the proof it is said that this similarity between whiteness and knowledge does not exist because to be similar is extrinsic to whiteness, not essential or intrinsic. But to be knowledge is something that can be extrinsic to God, indeed it is essential or intrinsic. Therefore, if the knowledge were removed more than the essence, the divine essence would exceed itself from the fact that to be knowledge does not suit God through an extrinsic denomination, but only intrinsically.

To the second , the minor is denied because not every intelligible thing has a cause.
In the second place, it would be able to be said by taking cause loosely for that which has being. The major is able to be denied because the Son is from the Father, and nevertheless is not posterior to him.
To the third , the antecedent is denied. To the proof it is said that it is true where power is distinguished from act, but this is not the sense here.

To the fourt , it is said that Anselm understand about impossibility with respect to a second cause and secundum quid, but not about impossibility absolutely. And in the same was speaks the Gospel,
no word is impossible with God
.

To the first against the second conclusion , the consequence is denied because not all parts are continuous, but if it is understood thus, he knows all things, that is there is nothing which he does not know, then in this way the consequent is conceded, but this is not against the conclusion in anyway. Nevertheless note that
Gregory
XXX
responds differently as well as
Hugolinus in distinction 35
XXX . Again,
Thomas Argentina
XXX
says that, just as in nature the motion of parts is because they are in some succession and are not able to be at the same time, so God is not able to consider all these parts which are able to occur successively from continuous division because it is from the nature of such parts that they are in becoming and never total finished being. And just as the power of God is not made imperfect by the fact that he is not able to produce that which is not producible, so neither is his knowledge made imperfect because he does not distinctly understand what is not distinctly intelligible at the same time.

To the second , the consequence is denied, and the proof is conceded regarding an understanding distinct from its own intellection, if there is any truth to this, but it is not conceded with respect to the divine which is its own intellection.

And it is said similarly
to the third , that the diversity of known objects does not always argue for a diversity of cognition because by the same cognition at the same time, namely by vision , I see at the same time black ink on a white parchment, and granted that this would be true in created things, nevertheless it is not true in the proposed.

To the argument from Augustine which
Alphonsus XXX
alleges that in this authority and similar ones he intends that the knowledge of God does not depend nor is caused by known things, as is clear in the examples
given by him in the text XXX .

To the first against the third conclusion , it is said, that a created being is a secondary object of the divine intellect is able to be understood in two ways, in one mode, as that begin is in its proper genus or species, in a another mode, as in the exemplative divine art. In the first mode it is said that it is able to be a secondary object, but in the second mode it would not be possible, and otherwise it would able to be said
that a motive and objective reason is suitable to no created being with respect to the divine cognitive power, but only a terminative reason

To the second , the antecedent is denied, and to the proof the case is admitted, but when it is argued that a is equal to b and c separately, therefore it is less than d, the consequence is denied when taking the word less distinctively, such that b is a multitude containing less than d, though d contains somethings which neither a nor c nor b contains, while it is nevertheless the case that there are as many parts in a as there are in d, not more and not less.
But against this it would be able to be objected thus that b is part of d and d is some amount, therefore d is greater than b. The consequence is clear because every whole is greater than its parts.

Here responds Gregory that one infinity is not properly said to be part of another, since something is equal to another according to that according to which it is said to be infinite, though a body infinite in length exceeds by infinity according to the breadth not according to the length.
In the second place, someone would say that this rule only holds for infinite magnitudes and infinite things. But if by saying that a body infinite and immeasurable in all directions and would be able to be separated by no one nor would anything be able to be added to it, thus it is in the proposed because the multitude of known things is absolutely infinite, therefore no addition to it is possible.

To the third , the consequence is denied because it would be proved similarly that this kind of multitude would be adequate to the entire capacity of possible being, such that nothing else would be possible or able to be produced, which is false.

To the fourth , the consequence is denied because whatever God understands he is able to understand, and conversely whatever God is able to understand he understands that he is able to understand and wishes himself to understand
In the second place, it is said that, if the power of God is understand as the power to produce something outside himself, then it is conceded improperly that God understands more than he is capable of producing because with respect to anything God is able to produce with respect to those things he is understanding, but not the converse. And the following consequence is denied, therefore God is not omnipotent because something is not therefore called omnipotent because it is able to produce everything imaginable, but because it is able to produce everything doable, aside from what is blameworthy.

To the first in the opposition , the consequent is conceded, and it is not the same in the case of God and creatures because in God it is the same thing to live, and to be, and to understand, but not in creatures.
To the second , the consequent is conceded.

Similarly
to the third , the consequent is conceded because there is eternal knowledge of each.

Praedictis adiciendum est
Lombardus, Sent. d. 34, c. 1
. The first conclusion of distinction 34: that the three divine persons are distinguished by properties, and are the same according to essence, such that the three persons are at the same time one God and one essence and individual somethings.
Second conclusion: that when it is said, the Son is what the Father is, it is understood according to substance, but not according to that which is said in relation to the other.

Third conclusion: that the use of the holy doctors admits this saying, the essence of the three persons is one, and the three persons are of one essence, but it is never ready in scripture that there is one God of three persons or three persons of one God.

The fourth conclusion: just as the essence is said about God according to substance, so goodness, wisdom, power, and those things that are said about God according to substance are at the same time said about the three persons and about them individually.
The fifth conclusion: that the one of the three persons is power, wisdom, and goodness, and the three persons are the same power, the same wisdom, and the same goodness.

Sixth conclusion: that though these are the same inwardly, nevertheless power is attributed to the Father, wisdom to the Son, and goodness to the Holy Spirit, so that it not be thought that the Father is impotent, the Son less wise, and the Holy Spirit puffed up or timid or cruel.

Seventh conclusion: that the Son is understood to be homoousion, that consubstantial, with the Father, whence the Son is called homoousion to the Father, that is of one same substance, and thus the Father is likewise said to be omnipotent.

Eight conclusion: that names said transumptively about God, like mirror, splendor, character, and similar names, are sad by reason of some similarity, such that hearing this some catholic understanding about God is understood.

Cumque supra disservimus . Prima conclusio distinctionis 35: quod scientia divina cum sit una et simplex, tamen propter varios rerum status et diversos effectus diversa sortitur vocabula quia quandoque dicitur praescientia, dispositio, providentia, praedestinatio,
et providentia.

Secunda conclusio: quod providentia seu praescientia est tantum respectu futurorum sed tam de bonis quam de malis dispositio est tantum de faciendis praedestinatio de hominibus salvandis et de bonis quibus haec liberantur a culpa et pena et in futuro coronabuntur in gloria providentia est gubernandorum et interdum accipitur pro praescientia sapientia vero ac scientia est de omnibus malis et bonis praeteritis praesentibus et futuris temporalibus et aeternis.

Tertia conclusio: quod praescientia praedestinatio et dispositio quantum ad illud quod sunt manerent et essent posito quod nullum esset futurum quia nihil aliud sunt quam divina essentia sed inquantum r?elatum important ad futura tunc non manerent si nihil essent futurum.
Quarta conclusio: quod si nulla esset futura adhuc in Deo esset scientia quae modo est quia scientia non solum est de temporalibus sed etiam de aeternis nec esset minor nec maior quam modo.

Quinta conclusio: quod omnia fuerunt in Deo ab aeterno nec aliter novit Deus res factans quam fiendas et dicuntur omnia esse in Deo vita non quod creatura sit creator vel quod ista corruptibilia sint essentialiter in Deo quia sunt in eius scientia quae est vita.
Sexta conclusio: quod tam praeterita quam futura sunt Deo praesentia quia quadam cognitione ineffabili suae sapientiae in eo sunt.
